Yet, as he contemplated the means—whether to starve himself, dash his head against the stones, or fashion a noose from his ragged garments—a fiercer emotion stirred within him. It was not despair, but defiance. The same spirit that had once driven him to seek justice now rebelled against the notion of surrender. To die would be to grant his enemies victory, to let Villefort, Danglars, and Fernand escape unscathed. No, he could not give them that satisfaction.  

Instead, he resolved to live—not as the broken prisoner of the Château d’If, but as an instrument of retribution. If God had forsaken him, then he would become his own avenger. The Count of Monte Cristo was born in that moment, not from hope, but from the ashes of vengeance.  

His thoughts turned to Abbé Faria, the wise old man who had been his sole companion in captivity. The abbé had spoken of hidden treasures, of power beyond imagination, and though Dantès had dismissed it as the ramblings of a dying man, he now clung to the possibility. If there was even a sliver of truth in Faria’s words, then escape was not merely a dream, but a necessity.  

With grim determination, he began to plan. The tunnel Faria had dug was incomplete, but it was a start. The guards were careless, their routines predictable. And if he could not break free by cunning, then he would wait, biding his time until fortune favored him. Death would not claim him—not yet.  

Days turned into weeks, weeks into months, and still Dantès labored in secret. His body grew weaker, but his resolve hardened like steel. Then, at last, opportunity came in the form of a storm. The sea raged against the cliffs, and in the chaos, he made his move. Wrapping himself in the abbé’s burial shroud, he allowed himself to be thrown into the waves, the guards believing him dead.  

The cold water shocked his senses, but he fought against the current, his will to survive overpowering even the fury of the ocean. When he finally dragged himself onto the shore, gasping and half-drowned, he knew that Edmond Dantès had died in the Château d’If. What emerged from the sea was something else entirely—a man reborn, with a single purpose burning in his heart.  

From that day forward, he would wear many faces, assume many names, but beneath them all lay the unshakable resolve of the Count of Monte Cristo. The world would come to know him, not as a victim, but as a force of reckoning. And those who had wronged him would learn too late that some punishments were far worse than death.  

For now, he would bide his time, gather his strength, and let his enemies believe themselves secure. Their day of judgment would come—and when it did, no mercy would be shown. The Count of Monte Cristo had risen, and with him, the promise of vengeance.

events.title: A Mysterious Sound Interrupts the Path to Death
detailed_summary: Dantès adhered to his plan, discarding his daily meals, initially with a sense of lightness, then more thoughtfully, and finally with sorrow, only his oath providing the strength to continue.
Intense hunger made previously unappetizing food seem desirable, and he would hold his plate for long periods, battling the urge to eat against his vow of despair.
As he weakened physically, experiencing dimming sight and hearing, he approached a state of stupor that brought an almost peaceful feeling, believing he was dying.
Suddenly, one evening, he heard a distinct, hollow scratching sound from the wall he lay against, a noise different from the usual prison sounds.

Despite his weakness, the sound ignited the prisoner's enduring hope for liberty, making him wonder if it was a divine sign or a loved one attempting rescue, though he also feared it was a deathbed hallucination.

The sound persisted for hours, ceased, then resumed louder and closer. When the jailer brought breakfast, Dantès, who had been silent for days, began to talk animatedly about trivial complaints to divert the jailer's attention from the noise, leading the jailer to believe him delirious.

Convinced it was another prisoner digging, but briefly fearing it might be workmen, Dantès drank the soup the jailer had brought to regain mental clarity, deciding not to die yet, and then devised a way to test the source of the noise by knocking on the wall.

He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him—at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret. Nothing but the recollection of his oath gave him strength to proceed. Hunger made viands once repugnant, now acceptable; he held the plate in his hand for an hour at a time, and gazed thoughtfully at the morsel of bad meat, of tainted fish, of black and mouldy bread. It was the last yearning for life contending with the resolution of despair; then his dungeon seemed less sombre, his prospects less desperate. He was still young—he was only four or five-and-twenty—he had nearly fifty years to live. What unforseen events might not open his prison door, and restore him to liberty? Then he raised to his lips the repast that, like a voluntary Tantalus, he refused himself; but he thought of his oath, and he would not break it. He persisted until, at last, he had not sufficient strength to rise and cast his supper out of the loophole. The next morning he could not see or hear; the jailer feared he was dangerously ill. Edmond hoped he was dying.
Thus the day passed away. Edmond felt a sort of stupor creeping over him which brought with it a feeling almost of content; the gnawing pain at his stomach had ceased; his thirst had abated; when he closed his eyes he saw myriads of lights dancing before them like the will-o’-the-wisps that play about the marshes. It was the twilight of that mysterious country called Death!
Suddenly, about nine o’clock in the evening, Edmond heard a hollow sound in the wall against which he was lying.
So many loathsome animals inhabited the prison, that their noise did not, in general, awake him; but whether abstinence had quickened his faculties, or whether the noise was really louder than usual, Edmond raised his head and listened. It was a continual scratching, as if made by a huge claw, a powerful tooth, or some iron instrument attacking the stones.
Although weakened, the young man’s brain instantly responded to the idea that haunts all prisoners—liberty! It seemed to him that heaven had at length taken pity on him, and had sent this noise to warn him on the very brink of the abyss. Perhaps one of those beloved ones he had so often thought of was thinking of him, and striving to diminish the distance that separated them.
No, no, doubtless he was deceived, and it was but one of those dreams that forerun death!
Edmond still heard the sound. It lasted nearly three hours; he then heard a noise of something falling, and all was silent.
Some hours afterwards it began again, nearer and more distinct. Edmond was intensely interested. Suddenly the jailer entered.
For a week since he had resolved to die, and during the four days that he had been carrying out his purpose, Edmond had not spoken to the attendant, had not answered him when he inquired what was the matter with him, and turned his face to the wall when he looked too curiously at him; but now the jailer might hear the noise and put an end to it, and so destroy a ray of something like hope that soothed his last moments.
The jailer brought him his breakfast. Dantès raised himself up and began to talk about everything; about the bad quality of the food, about the coldness of his dungeon, grumbling and complaining, in order to have an excuse for speaking louder, and wearying the patience of his jailer, who out of kindness of heart had brought broth and white bread for his prisoner.
Fortunately, he fancied that Dantès was delirious; and placing the food on the rickety table, he withdrew. Edmond listened, and the sound became more and more distinct.
“There can be no doubt about it,” thought he; “it is some prisoner who is striving to obtain his freedom. Oh, if I were only there to help him!”
Suddenly another idea took possession of his mind, so used to misfortune, that it was scarcely capable of hope—the idea that the noise was made by workmen the governor had ordered to repair the neighboring dungeon.
It was easy to ascertain this; but how could he risk the question? It was easy to call his jailer’s attention to the noise, and watch his countenance as he listened; but might he not by this means destroy hopes far more important than the short-lived satisfaction of his own curiosity? Unfortunately, Edmond’s brain was still so feeble that he could not bend his thoughts to anything in particular. He saw but one means of restoring lucidity and clearness to his judgment. He turned his eyes towards the soup which the jailer had brought, rose, staggered towards it, raised the vessel to his lips, and drank off the contents with a feeling of indescribable pleasure.
He had the resolution to stop with this. He had often heard that shipwrecked persons had died through having eagerly devoured too much food. Edmond replaced on the table the bread he was about to devour, and returned to his couch—he did not wish to die. He soon felt that his ideas became again collected—he could think, and strengthen his thoughts by reasoning. Then he said to himself:
“I must put this to the test, but without compromising anybody. If it is a workman, I need but knock against the wall, and he will cease to work, in order to find out who is knocking, and why he does so; but as his occupation is sanctioned by the governor, he will soon resume it. If, on the contrary, it is a prisoner, the noise I make will alarm him, he will cease, and not begin again until he thinks everyone is asleep.”
Edmond rose again, but this time his legs did not tremble, and his sight was clear; he went to a corner of his dungeon, detached a stone, and with it knocked against the wall where the sound came. He struck thrice.

He kept his word; twice a day he cast out, through the barred aperture, the provisions his jailer brought him—at first gayly, then with deliberation, and at last with regret.  

At first, the act was one of defiance, a silent protest against the injustice that had condemned him to this living tomb. Edmond Dantès, once so full of life and hope, now found solace in this small rebellion. Each crust of bread, each meager portion of soup he discarded was a declaration that he would not be broken, that his spirit remained unyielding even as his body weakened.  

But as the days stretched into weeks, and the weeks into months, his resolve began to waver. Hunger gnawed at him, a relentless tormentor that whispered doubts into his weary mind. The bread, once so easily discarded, now seemed a cruel taunt as it tumbled into the abyss below. His hands trembled as he pushed it through the bars, his stomach clenching in protest.  

Yet still, he persisted.  

The jailer, a man of few words and fewer sympathies, noticed nothing amiss. To him, Dantès was but another prisoner, another soul to be forgotten in the bowels of the Château d’If. He delivered the rations with the same indifference, never questioning why the young man grew thinner, why his eyes burned with a feverish intensity.  

Then came the day when Dantès could bear it no longer. As he lifted the bread to cast it away, his fingers tightened around it involuntarily. The scent of it—stale though it was—filled his nostrils, and for a moment, he wavered. His mouth watered, his body screaming for sustenance.  

But he remembered his oath.  

With a groan of anguish, he hurled the bread into the darkness, collapsing against the cold stone wall as tears of frustration stung his eyes. He had sworn to refuse their food, to reject the meager charity of his captors until he was either free or dead. And yet, the human instinct for survival warred violently with his pride.  

That night, as he lay shivering on the damp floor, he dreamed of feasts—of succulent meats, ripe fruits, and fine wines. He saw himself at a grand table, surrounded by laughter and light, his father’s proud smile warming his heart. But the vision faded as quickly as it had come, leaving him alone once more in the suffocating blackness of his cell.  

When morning came, the jailer arrived with the usual portion. Dantès stared at it, his breath coming in shallow gasps. His fingers twitched, but this time, he did not reach for it. Instead, he turned his face to the wall, his body trembling with exhaustion.  

The jailer shrugged and left the food on the floor, muttering something under his breath about madmen and fools.  

For hours, Dantès lay still, his mind a whirlwind of doubt and determination. Then, with a sudden, desperate motion, he seized the bread and devoured it in ragged bites, his body overriding his will. Shame flooded him even as relief soothed his aching stomach.  

He had broken his vow.  

But in that moment of weakness, something shifted within him. The blind, reckless defiance that had sustained him thus far gave way to something colder, sharper—a calculating resolve. If he was to survive, if he was ever to escape this hell, he would need more than pride. He would need patience. Cunning. A plan.  

And so, as the days passed, Dantès ceased his futile protest. He ate what was given, not with gratitude, but with quiet purpose. He observed, he listened, he waited.  

For the first time since his imprisonment, he began to think not of death, but of revenge.

events.title: Labor, Ingenuity, and First Contact Through the Wall
detailed_summary: The moment Dantès knocked, the scratching noise stopped abruptly. After hours of silence, he ate some bread and water, regaining strength and hope, convinced it was a fellow prisoner.
For three days, he impatiently waited for the sound to resume. One evening, he detected a faint movement, realizing the other prisoner was now using a lever, not a chisel.

Inspired to help, Dantès sought a tool. He broke his water jug, concealing sharp fragments. When the jailer brought a replacement, Dantès began to work on the wall, scraping away plaster, lamenting the years wasted in despair.

He uncovered stonework but couldn't dislodge a large stone with his weak nails or jug fragments. He then ingeniously tricked the jailer into breaking his plate and subsequently leaving the iron saucepan in his cell.
Using the saucepan's iron handle as a lever, Dantès successfully removed the stone, creating an opening. He carefully hid the debris.
The jailer, upon his next visit, grumbled about the broken plate and decided to permanently leave the saucepan for Dantès' soup, an outcome that filled Dantès with immense gratitude.

Noticing the other prisoner had ceased working, Dantès continued his own efforts, driven by the idea of reaching his neighbor if his neighbor wouldn't come to him. He encountered a wooden beam obstructing his path.
In a moment of profound despair at this new obstacle, after all his renewed hope, he cried out to God, questioning why he was being subjected to such torment.
A voice, seemingly from beneath the earth, hollow and sepulchral, responded to his cry, asking who spoke of God and despair simultaneously, causing Dantès to react with terror and awe.

events.text_segment:
At the first blow the sound ceased, as if by magic.
Edmond listened intently; an hour passed, two hours passed, and no sound was heard from the wall—all was silent there.
Full of hope, Edmond swallowed a few mouthfuls of bread and water, and, thanks to the vigor of his constitution, found himself well-nigh recovered.
The day passed away in utter silence—night came without recurrence of the noise.
“It is a prisoner,” said Edmond joyfully. His brain was on fire, and life and energy returned.
The night passed in perfect silence. Edmond did not close his eyes.
In the morning the jailer brought him fresh provisions—he had already devoured those of the previous day; he ate these listening anxiously for the sound, walking round and round his cell, shaking the iron bars of the loophole, restoring vigor and agility to his limbs by exercise, and so preparing himself for his future destiny. At intervals he listened to learn if the noise had not begun again, and grew impatient at the prudence of the prisoner, who did not guess he had been disturbed by a captive as anxious for liberty as himself.
Three days passed—seventy-two long tedious hours which he counted off by minutes!
At length one evening, as the jailer was visiting him for the last time that night, Dantès, with his ear for the hundredth time at the wall, fancied he heard an almost imperceptible movement among the stones. He moved away, walked up and down his cell to collect his thoughts, and then went back and listened.
The matter was no longer doubtful. Something was at work on the other side of the wall; the prisoner had discovered the danger, and had substituted a lever for a chisel.
Encouraged by this discovery, Edmond determined to assist the indefatigable laborer. He began by moving his bed, and looked around for anything with which he could pierce the wall, penetrate the moist cement, and displace a stone.
He saw nothing, he had no knife or sharp instrument, the window grating was of iron, but he had too often assured himself of its solidity. All his furniture consisted of a bed, a chair, a table, a pail, and a jug. The bed had iron clamps, but they were screwed to the wood, and it would have required a screw-driver to take them off. The table and chair had nothing, the pail had once possessed a handle, but that had been removed.
Dantès had but one resource, which was to break the jug, and with one of the sharp fragments attack the wall. He let the jug fall on the floor, and it broke in pieces.
Dantès concealed two or three of the sharpest fragments in his bed, leaving the rest on the floor. The breaking of his jug was too natural an accident to excite suspicion. Edmond had all the night to work in, but in the darkness he could not do much, and he soon felt that he was working against something very hard; he pushed back his bed, and waited for day.
All night he heard the subterranean workman, who continued to mine his way. Day came, the jailer entered. Dantès told him that the jug had fallen from his hands while he was drinking, and the jailer went grumblingly to fetch another, without giving himself the trouble to remove the fragments of the broken one. He returned speedily, advised the prisoner to be more careful, and departed.
Dantès heard joyfully the key grate in the lock; he listened until the sound of steps died away, and then, hastily displacing his bed, saw by the faint light that penetrated into his cell, that he had labored uselessly the previous evening in attacking the stone instead of removing the plaster that surrounded it.
The damp had rendered it friable, and Dantès was able to break it off—in small morsels, it is true, but at the end of half an hour he had scraped off a handful; a mathematician might have calculated that in two years, supposing that the rock was not encountered, a passage twenty feet long and two feet broad, might be formed.
The prisoner reproached himself with not having thus employed the hours he had passed in vain hopes, prayer, and despondency. During the six years that he had been imprisoned, what might he not have accomplished?
This idea imparted new energy, and in three days he had succeeded, with the utmost precaution, in removing the cement, and exposing the stone-work. The wall was built of rough stones, among which, to give strength to the structure, blocks of hewn stone were at intervals imbedded. It was one of these he had uncovered, and which he must remove from its socket.
Dantès strove to do this with his nails, but they were too weak. The fragments of the jug broke, and after an hour of useless toil, Dantès paused with anguish on his brow.
Was he to be thus stopped at the beginning, and was he to wait inactive until his fellow workman had completed his task? Suddenly an idea occurred to him—he smiled, and the perspiration dried on his forehead.
The jailer always brought Dantès’ soup in an iron saucepan; this saucepan contained soup for both prisoners, for Dantès had noticed that it was either quite full, or half empty, according as the turnkey gave it to him or to his companion first.
The handle of this saucepan was of iron; Dantès would have given ten years of his life in exchange for it.
The jailer was accustomed to pour the contents of the saucepan into Dantès’ plate, and Dantès, after eating his soup with a wooden spoon, washed the plate, which thus served for every day. Now when evening came Dantès put his plate on the ground near the door; the jailer, as he entered, stepped on it and broke it.
This time he could not blame Dantès. He was wrong to leave it there, but the jailer was wrong not to have looked before him. The jailer, therefore, only grumbled. Then he looked about for something to pour the soup into; Dantès’ entire dinner service consisted of one plate—there was no alternative.
“Leave the saucepan,” said Dantès; “you can take it away when you bring me my breakfast.”
This advice was to the jailer’s taste, as it spared him the necessity of making another trip. He left the saucepan.
Dantès was beside himself with joy. All day he toiled on untiringly, and by the evening he had succeeded in extracting ten handfuls of plaster and fragments of stone. When the hour for his jailer’s visit arrived, Dantès straightened the handle of the saucepan as well as he could, and placed it in its accustomed place. The turnkey poured his ration of soup into it, together with the fish—for thrice a week the prisoners were deprived of meat. “Who talks of God and despair at the same time?” said a voice that seemed to come from beneath the earth, and, deadened by the distance, sounded hollow and sepulchral in the young man’s ears. Edmond’s hair stood on end, and he rose to his knees.

At the first blow the sound ceased, as if by magic. Edmond Dantès paused, his heart pounding in his chest. The silence that followed was more unnerving than the mysterious tapping had been. He strained his ears, listening for any sign of movement beyond the thick stone walls of his cell in the Château d’If.  

For weeks—or was it months?—he had been counting the days by the faint light that filtered through the narrow slit in his dungeon. The isolation had nearly driven him mad, but the sudden noise had reignited a spark of hope. Someone, or something, was trying to communicate with him.  

He raised the iron leg of his cot once more and struck the wall again, this time with more force. A hollow echo reverberated through the stone. His breath caught. There was a cavity behind the wall!  

Then, just as suddenly as it had stopped, the tapping resumed—three quick raps, followed by a pause, then two more. Dantès’ pulse quickened. It was a code. He had heard sailors use something similar aboard the *Pharaon*.  

With trembling fingers, he tapped back in response: two strikes, then three.  

The unseen prisoner on the other side answered immediately. A slow, deliberate rhythm this time—one that Dantès recognized as the beginning of a pattern. His mind raced. Could it be? Was this the work of fate, or merely another cruel trick of his jailers?  

He pressed his ear against the cold stone, his entire body tense with anticipation. The tapping continued, methodical and precise. It was no accident. Someone was trying to reach him.  

And for the first time since his unjust imprisonment, Edmond Dantès dared to hope.  

---  

### **The Discovery of the Tunnel**  

Days passed in a feverish blur as Dantès and his unseen companion exchanged messages through the wall. The prisoner on the other side was none other than Abbé Faria, an Italian priest and scholar who had been imprisoned for his political beliefs. Through their coded communications, Faria revealed that he had been digging a tunnel for years—one that had accidentally led him to Dantès’ cell instead of freedom.  

At first, Dantès was disappointed. But Faria’s knowledge and wisdom soon became a beacon of light in the darkness. The old man taught him history, science, philosophy, and languages, transforming the once-naïve sailor into a learned and cunning man.  

Most importantly, Faria shared the secret of a vast treasure hidden on the island of Monte Cristo—a fortune that could make a man powerful beyond imagination.  

---  

### **The Betrayal Revealed**  

As their bond deepened, Faria deduced the truth behind Dantès’ imprisonment. Through careful reasoning, he uncovered the conspiracy that had condemned the young man to the Château d’If.  

“Your so-called friend, Fernand Mondego, coveted your fiancée, Mercédès,” Faria explained. “And Danglars, your envious shipmate, sought to steal your future as captain. Together, with the corrupt prosecutor Villefort, they fabricated evidence of your treason.”  

The revelation struck Dantès like a physical blow. The men he had trusted had destroyed his life without remorse. A fire ignited in his chest—not just of anger, but of purpose.  

“If I ever escape,” he vowed, his voice low and dangerous, “I will make them pay.”  

---  

### **The Death of Faria and the Path to Freedom**  

Months turned into years. Just as their escape plan neared completion, tragedy struck. Faria, weakened by age and illness, suffered a fatal seizure. With his dying breath, he urged Dantès to continue the tunnel alone and claim the treasure of Monte Cristo.  

Grief-stricken but determined, Dantès carried out a daring plan. He sewed himself into Faria’s burial shroud, knowing the jailers would throw the body into the sea. The risk was immense—if they discovered his ruse, he would be executed on the spot.  

But fate favored him. The guards, as expected, tossed the weighted sack into the churning waters below the cliffs of the Château d’If. Dantès barely managed to cut himself free before drowning. Exhausted but alive, he washed ashore on a nearby island.  

He was free.  

---  

### **The Transformation into the Count of Monte Cristo**  

With Faria’s treasure, Dantès reinvented himself. He became the enigmatic and wealthy Count of Monte Cristo, a figure of mystery and power. His years of suffering had forged him into something far more dangerous than the innocent sailor he had once been.  

He returned to Marseille, not as Edmond Dantès, but as a shadow of vengeance. One by one, he would find those who had betrayed him.  

Fernand. Danglars. Villefort.  

They would all learn that some debts could never be escaped.  

And so began the Count’s meticulous revenge—a web of deception, ruin, and poetic justice that would shake the very foundations of their lives.  

For Edmond Dantès was dead.  

And the Count of Monte Cristo showed no mercy.

detailed_summary: Dantès, astonished and terrified, acknowledged the human voice—the first he'd heard besides his jailer's in years.

He and the voice exchanged information: they were both unhappy prisoners; Dantès was a French sailor named Edmond Dantès, imprisoned since February 1815 for allegedly conspiring for Napoleon's return.
The voice revealed he had been imprisoned since 1811, shocking Dantès with the length of his captivity, and was unaware of Napoleon's abdication.
The other prisoner, identifying himself only as No. 27, explained that a miscalculation in his escape plans led him to Dantès' cell instead of the outer fortress wall and proximity to the sea.
No. 27 advised Dantès to seal his excavation and wait. Sensing mistrust and fearing abandonment, Dantès passionately swore his loyalty, threatening self-destruction if left alone.
Reassured by Dantès' youth (not yet twenty-six) and fervent pleas, No. 27 promised not to forsake him and to provide a signal after calculating their chances.
Dantès, overjoyed at the prospect of companionship and potential liberty, expressed his deep loneliness and offered his unwavering affection and loyalty, whether as a comrade or a son.
No. 27 confirmed, "tomorrow," leaving Dantès ecstatic. He spent the day in anticipation, resolving to kill the jailer if any attempt was made to separate him from his new acquaintance.
The next morning, after the jailer's departure and an exchange of knocks, No. 27 resumed work. Suddenly, the floor in Dantès' cell gave way, and from the resulting hole, a man emerged into his cell.

“Ah,” said he, “I hear a human voice.” Edmond had not heard anyone speak save his jailer for four or five years; and a jailer is no man to a prisoner—he is a living door, a barrier of flesh and blood adding strength to restraints of oak and iron.
“In the name of Heaven,” cried Dantès, “speak again, though the sound of your voice terrifies me. Who are you?”
“Who are you?” said the voice.
“An unhappy prisoner,” replied Dantès, who made no hesitation in answering.
“Of what country?”
“A Frenchman.”
“Your name?”
“Edmond Dantès.”
“Your profession?”
“A sailor.”
“How long have you been here?”
“Since the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Your crime?”
“I am innocent.”
“But of what are you accused?”
“Of having conspired to aid the emperor’s return.”
“What! For the emperor’s return?—the emperor is no longer on the throne, then?”
“He abdicated at Fontainebleau in 1814, and was sent to the Island of Elba. But how long have you been here that you are ignorant of all this?”
“Since 1811.”
Dantès shuddered; this man had been four years longer than himself in prison.
“Do not dig any more,” said the voice; “only tell me how high up is your excavation?”
“On a level with the floor.”
“How is it concealed?”
“Behind my bed.”
“Has your bed been moved since you have been a prisoner?”
“No.”
“What does your chamber open on?”
“A corridor.”
“And the corridor?”
“On a court.”
“Alas!” murmured the voice.
“Oh, what is the matter?” cried Dantès.
“I have made a mistake owing to an error in my plans. I took the wrong angle, and have come out fifteen feet from where I intended. I took the wall you are mining for the outer wall of the fortress.”
“But then you would be close to the sea?”
“That is what I hoped.”
“And supposing you had succeeded?”
“I should have thrown myself into the sea, gained one of the islands near here—the Isle de Daume or the Isle de Tiboulen—and then I should have been safe.”
“Could you have swum so far?”
“Heaven would have given me strength; but now all is lost.”
“All?”
“Yes; stop up your excavation carefully, do not work any more, and wait until you hear from me.”
“Tell me, at least, who you are?”
“I am—I am No. 27.”
“You mistrust me, then,” said Dantès. Edmond fancied he heard a bitter laugh resounding from the depths.
“Oh, I am a Christian,” cried Dantès, guessing instinctively that this man meant to abandon him. “I swear to you by him who died for us that naught shall induce me to breathe one syllable to my jailers; but I conjure you do not abandon me. If you do, I swear to you, for I have got to the end of my strength, that I will dash my brains out against the wall, and you will have my death to reproach yourself with.”
“How old are you? Your voice is that of a young man.”
“I do not know my age, for I have not counted the years I have been here. All I do know is, that I was just nineteen when I was arrested, the 28th of February, 1815.”
“Not quite twenty-six!” murmured the voice; “at that age he cannot be a traitor.”
“Oh, no, no,” cried Dantès. “I swear to you again, rather than betray you, I would allow myself to be hacked in pieces!”
“You have done well to speak to me, and ask for my assistance, for I was about to form another plan, and leave you; but your age reassures me. I will not forget you. Wait.”
“How long?”
“I must calculate our chances; I will give you the signal.”
“But you will not leave me; you will come to me, or you will let me come to you. We will escape, and if we cannot escape we will talk; you of those whom you love, and I of those whom I love. You must love somebody?”
“No, I am alone in the world.”
“Then you will love me. If you are young, I will be your comrade; if you are old, I will be your son. I have a father who is seventy if he yet lives; I only love him and a young girl called Mercédès. My father has not yet forgotten me, I am sure, but God alone knows if she loves me still; I shall love you as I loved my father.”
“It is well,” returned the voice; “tomorrow.”
These few words were uttered with an accent that left no doubt of his sincerity; Dantès rose, dispersed the fragments with the same precaution as before, and pushed his bed back against the wall. He then gave himself up to his happiness. He would no longer be alone. He was, perhaps, about to regain his liberty; at the worst, he would have a companion, and captivity that is shared is but half captivity. Plaints made in common are almost prayers, and prayers where two or three are gathered together invoke the mercy of heaven.
All day Dantès walked up and down his cell. He sat down occasionally on his bed, pressing his hand on his heart. At the slightest noise he bounded towards the door. Once or twice the thought crossed his mind that he might be separated from this unknown, whom he loved already; and then his mind was made up—when the jailer moved his bed and stooped to examine the opening, he would kill him with his water jug. He would be condemned to die, but he was about to die of grief and despair when this miraculous noise recalled him to life.
The jailer came in the evening. Dantès was on his bed. It seemed to him that thus he better guarded the unfinished opening. Doubtless there was a strange expression in his eyes, for the jailer said, “Come, are you going mad again?”
Dantès did not answer; he feared that the emotion of his voice would betray him. The jailer went away shaking his head. Night came; Dantès hoped that his neighbor would profit by the silence to address him, but he was mistaken. The next morning, however, just as he removed his bed from the wall, he heard three knocks; he threw himself on his knees.
“Is it you?” said he; “I am here.”
“Is your jailer gone?”
“Yes,” said Dantès; “he will not return until the evening; so that we have twelve hours before us.”
“I can work, then?” said the voice.
“Oh, yes, yes; this instant, I entreat you.”
In a moment that part of the floor on which Dantès was resting his two hands, as he knelt with his head in the opening, suddenly gave way; he drew back smartly, while a mass of stones and earth disappeared in a hole that opened beneath the aperture he himself had formed. Then from the bottom of this passage, the depth of which it was impossible to measure, he saw appear, first the head, then the shoulders, and lastly the body of a man, who sprang lightly into his cell.

“Ah,” said he, “I hear a human voice.”  

Edmond had not heard any one speak save his jailer for four or five years; and a jailer is not a man to a prisoner—he is a living door, a barrier of flesh and blood adding strength to restraints of iron and wood.  

“In the name of heaven,” cried Dantès, “speak again, though the sound of your voice terrifies me. Who are you?”  

“Who are you?” said the voice.  

“An unhappy prisoner,” replied Dantès, who made no hesitation in answering.  

“Of what country?”  

“A Frenchman.”  

“Your name?”  

“Edmond Dantès.”  

“Your profession?”  

“A sailor.”  

“How long have you been here?”  

“Since the 28th of February, 1815.”  

“Your crime?”  

“I am innocent.”  

“But of what are you accused?”  

“Of having conspired for the return of Napoleon.”  

“What! For the return of the emperor?”  

“Yes.”  

“How! Do you then know him?”  

“No; but I was acquainted with a person who was very intimate with him.”  

“Who was that?”  

“M. Noirtier.”  

“M. Noirtier, of Villefort?”  

“Yes.”  

“Did you know him?”  

“I was his secretary.”  

“And he is now—”  

“Dead, I believe.”  

“Since when?”  

“Since 1814.”  

“How came you here?”  

“I was arrested at Marseilles.”  

“In the same way as I was at Paris?”  

“Yes.”  

“What was done to you?”  

“I was conducted before a tribunal, interrogated, and then conveyed to the Château d’If.”  

“And I also.”  

“But you—you were not interrogated?”  

“No; M. d’Avrigny, to whom I was known, obtained an order from the minister to dispense with that formality.”  

“Ah, yes; I know he was all-powerful under the emperor.”  

“And you have been here since 1815?”  

“Yes.”  

“And how old were you when you were arrested?”  

“I was scarcely twenty.”  

“So young!—and since then?”  

“Here I am.”

“They have remained as they were.”

"Ah," said he, "I hear a human voice."  

The words echoed faintly through the damp, oppressive darkness of the Château d'If, where the prisoner had long since lost track of time. Edmond Dantès, once a promising young sailor with a bright future, now a forgotten inmate in the bowels of the infamous prison, lifted his head from the cold stone floor. His emaciated frame trembled with exhaustion, but his spirit, though battered, had not yet been extinguished.  

For years, he had endured the silence, the isolation, the crushing weight of injustice. The walls of his cell had become his world, and the occasional scurrying of rats his only company. But now—now there was something different. A sound. A voice.  

Dantès pressed his ear against the rough stone, straining to hear more. The voice was muffled, distant, but unmistakably human. It was the first sign of another living soul he had encountered in what felt like an eternity.  

"Who is there?" he called out, his voice hoarse from disuse.  

For a moment, there was no response. Then, faintly, as if carried by the very walls themselves, came the reply:  

"A fellow prisoner, like yourself."  

The voice was old, weary, yet tinged with a strange resilience. Dantès felt a surge of hope—or was it madness? Had his mind finally broken under the strain of solitude?  

"No," he whispered to himself. "This is real."  

He scrambled to his feet, his chains clanking against the stone. "Where are you?" he demanded. "How long have you been here?"  

A dry chuckle echoed back. "Longer than you, my friend. Much longer."  

Dantès pressed his hands against the wall, as if he could somehow reach through it. "Who are you?"  

There was a pause, then the voice replied, "A man who was once something more than this. But names matter little in a place like this. Tell me, young one, what crime did you commit to be buried alive in this tomb?"  

Dantès clenched his fists. "No crime," he said bitterly. "I was betrayed."  

"Ah," the voice murmured knowingly. "Betrayal is a familiar companion in these walls. And who was it that condemned you?"  

"A jealous rival," Dantès spat. "A coward who could not bear to see me happy."  

The old prisoner sighed. "The world outside is cruel, but the cruelty of men is sharper still. Tell me your story, and perhaps I can offer you something in return."  

And so, for the first time in years, Dantès spoke. He told of his love for Mercédès, his bright future as a captain, the conspiracy that had ensnared him, and the false charge of treason that had sealed his fate. As he spoke, the weight on his chest seemed to lessen, as if the very act of sharing his pain had given him strength.  

When he finished, the voice was silent for a long moment. Then it said, "You have suffered greatly, Edmond Dantès. But suffering can forge a man into something greater—if he has the will to endure it."  

Dantès frowned. "What do you mean?"  

"I mean," the voice said slowly, "that I can teach you. I can give you knowledge, wisdom, the tools to survive—and perhaps, one day, to escape."  

Dantès's heart pounded. "Escape? From the Château d'If?"  

"Nothing is impossible," the voice replied cryptically. "But first, you must be patient. You must learn."  

And so began an unlikely partnership between the two prisoners, separated by stone but united in their defiance. Through the walls, the old man—who revealed himself to be the Abbé Faria, a learned scholar imprisoned for his political beliefs—taught Dantès history, philosophy, languages, and the sciences. With each passing day, Dantès's mind grew sharper, his resolve stronger.  

But more than knowledge, Faria gave him something far more precious: hope. The hope that one day, justice would be served. That the betrayers would pay. That Edmond Dantès would rise again—not as a helpless victim, but as a force to be reckoned with.  

And so, in the darkness of the Château d'If, the Count of Monte Cristo was born.

His thin face, deeply furrowed by care, and the bold outline of his strongly marked features, betokened a man more accustomed to exercise his mental faculties than his physical strength. Large drops of perspiration were now standing on his brow, while the garments that hung about him were so ragged that one could only guess at the pattern upon which they had originally been fashioned.
The stranger might have numbered sixty or sixty-five years; but a certain briskness and appearance of vigor in his movements made it probable that he was aged more from captivity than the course of time. He received the enthusiastic greeting of his young acquaintance with evident pleasure, as though his chilled affections were rekindled and invigorated by his contact with one so warm and ardent. He thanked him with grateful cordiality for his kindly welcome, although he must at that moment have been suffering bitterly to find another dungeon where he had fondly reckoned on discovering a means of regaining his liberty.
“Let us first see,” said he, “whether it is possible to remove the traces of my entrance here—our future tranquillity depends upon our jailers being entirely ignorant of it.”
Advancing to the opening, he stooped and raised the stone easily in spite of its weight; then, fitting it into its place, he said:
“You removed this stone very carelessly; but I suppose you had no tools to aid you.”
“Why,” exclaimed Dantès, with astonishment, “do you possess any?”
“I made myself some; and with the exception of a file, I have all that are necessary,—a chisel, pincers, and lever.”
“Oh, how I should like to see these products of your industry and patience.”
“Well, in the first place, here is my chisel.”
So saying, he displayed a sharp strong blade, with a handle made of beechwood.
“And with what did you contrive to make that?” inquired Dantès.
“With one of the clamps of my bedstead; and this very tool has sufficed me to hollow out the road by which I came hither, a distance of about fifty feet.”
“Fifty feet!” responded Dantès, almost terrified.

“Do not speak so loud, young man—don’t speak so loud. It frequently occurs in a state prison like this, that persons are stationed outside the doors of the cells purposely to overhear the conversation of the prisoners.”
“But they believe I am shut up alone here.”
“That makes no difference.”
“And you say that you dug your way a distance of fifty feet to get here?”
“I do; that is about the distance that separates your chamber from mine; only, unfortunately, I did not curve aright; for want of the necessary geometrical instruments to calculate my scale of proportion, instead of taking an ellipsis of forty feet, I made it fifty. I expected, as I told you, to reach the outer wall, pierce through it, and throw myself into the sea; I have, however, kept along the corridor on which your chamber opens, instead of going beneath it. My labor is all in vain, for I find that the corridor looks into a courtyard filled with soldiers.”
“That’s true,” said Dantès; “but the corridor you speak of only bounds one side of my cell; there are three others—do you know anything of their situation?”
“This one is built against the solid rock, and it would take ten experienced miners, duly furnished with the requisite tools, as many years to perforate it. This adjoins the lower part of the governor’s apartments, and were we to work our way through, we should only get into some lock-up cellars, where we must necessarily be recaptured. The fourth and last side of your cell faces on—faces on—stop a minute, now where does it face?”
The wall of which he spoke was the one in which was fixed the loophole by which light was admitted to the chamber. This loophole, which gradually diminished in size as it approached the outside, to an opening through which a child could not have passed, was, for better security, furnished with three iron bars, so as to quiet all apprehensions even in the mind of the most suspicious jailer as to the possibility of a prisoner’s escape. As the stranger asked the question, he dragged the table beneath the window.
“Climb up,” said he to Dantès.
The young man obeyed, mounted on the table, and, divining the wishes of his companion, placed his back securely against the wall and held out both hands. The stranger, whom as yet Dantès knew only by the number of his cell, sprang up with an agility by no means to be expected in a person of his years, and, light and steady on his feet as a cat or a lizard, climbed from the table to the outstretched hands of Dantès, and from them to his shoulders; then, bending double, for the ceiling of the dungeon prevented him from holding himself erect, he managed to slip his head between the upper bars of the window, so as to be able to command a perfect view from top to bottom.
An instant afterwards he hastily drew back his head, saying, “I thought so!” and sliding from the shoulders of Dantès as dextrously as he had ascended, he nimbly leaped from the table to the ground.

“Forgive me,” he muttered. “But I cannot bear this injustice any longer. My father—”  

The old man raised a trembling hand. “Justice,” he murmured, “is a word that means little to those who have been wronged. It is a luxury for the powerful, a dream for the weak.” His voice was soft, yet it carried the weight of bitter experience.  

The young man clenched his fists. “Then what must I do? Am I to accept this fate—this theft of my family’s honor?”  

A faint, knowing smile touched the old man’s lips. “Patience,” he said. “The wheel of fortune turns, though it may grind slowly. There are forces at work in this world that even the proudest cannot defy.”  

The young man leaned forward, his eyes searching the old man’s face. “You speak as if you know something—something of my father’s enemies.”  

The old man’s gaze grew distant. “I know many things,” he said. “But knowledge is a blade that must be wielded with care. To strike too soon is to invite disaster.”  

A silence fell between them, broken only by the murmur of other patrons and the occasional clink of glasses. At last, the young man sighed. “Then what would you have me do?”  

The old man leaned closer, his voice dropping to a whisper. “Watch. Wait. Learn. The day will come when the scales tip, when those who have wronged you grow careless in their arrogance. And when that day arrives—” He paused, his eyes gleaming like coals in the darkness. “—you must be ready.”  

The young man swallowed hard. “And if I fail?”  

The old man’s expression hardened. “Then you will join the countless others who have been crushed beneath the weight of their enemies’ power. But if you succeed—” He leaned back, folding his arms. “—you will have more than vengeance. You will have justice.”  

The young man exhaled slowly, his mind racing. He had come to this tavern seeking answers, but now he felt as though he stood at the edge of a precipice, staring into an abyss.  

“Who are you?” he asked at last.  

The old man’s smile returned, though it held no warmth. “A friend,” he said. “Or perhaps a ghost. It matters little. What matters is that you understand this: the path you walk is dangerous, and there is no turning back.”  

The young man nodded, his resolve hardening. “Then I will walk it.”  

The old man raised his glass in a silent toast. “To fate,” he murmured. “May it favor the bold.”  

And as the young man left the tavern, the weight of the old man’s words settled upon him like a cloak. He did not yet know how deep the conspiracy ran, nor the true nature of the forces arrayed against him. But one thing was certain—his life would never be the same.  

For in that dim corner, beneath the flickering candlelight, he had glimpsed the shadow of destiny. And destiny, as the old man had implied, was not to be trifled with.

“What was it that you thought?” asked the young man anxiously, in his turn descending from the table.
The elder prisoner pondered the matter. “Yes,” said he at length, “it is so. This side of your chamber looks out upon a kind of open gallery, where patrols are continually passing, and sentries keep watch day and night.”

“Certain. I saw the soldier’s shape and the top of his musket; that made me draw in my head so quickly, for I was fearful he might also see me.”
“Well?” inquired Dantès.

“Then——” pursued the young man eagerly.

events.title: Faria's Political Ideals and Inquiry about Reputed Madness
detailed_summary: Abbé Faria continues his musings, drawing parallels with English history and predicting a similar cycle in France involving new rulers, concessions to the people, a constitution, and eventual liberty, telling Dantès he is young enough to witness these events.
Dantès skeptically remarks that seeing such events unfold depends on him ever leaving prison.
Faria concedes their captive state but admits there are moments his mind transcends the prison walls, making him feel free.
Dantès then inquires about the reason for Faria's imprisonment.

Faria explains he was incarcerated in 1807 for conceiving a plan to unify Italy into a single, powerful empire, a vision Napoleon later attempted to realize. He had sought to consolidate Italy's petty principalities, much like Machiavelli, but was betrayed by a 'crowned simpleton' he had mistaken for his 'Cæsar Borgia'.
He laments that Italy seems fated to misfortune, referencing failed attempts by Alexander VI and Clement VII, and Napoleon's incomplete work, then bows his head in sorrow.
Dantès finds it difficult to comprehend risking one's life for such abstract political goals, his understanding limited to Napoleon and not historical figures like Clement VII or Alexander VI.
Dantès then cautiously asks if Faria is the priest widely believed to be 'ill' or, as Faria interjects, 'mad'.
Faria, with a bitter smile, acknowledges that he is indeed the 'poor mad prisoner' of Château d’If, whose supposed insanity has been a source of amusement for visitors for years.

“Yes, yes,” continued he, “’Twill be the same as it was in England. After Charles I., Cromwell; after Cromwell, Charles II., and then James II., and then some son-in-law or relation, some Prince of Orange, a stadtholder who becomes a king. Then new concessions to the people, then a constitution, then liberty. Ah, my friend!” said the abbé, turning towards Dantès, and surveying him with the kindling gaze of a prophet, “you are young, you will see all this come to pass.”
“Probably, if ever I get out of prison!”
“True,” replied Faria, “we are prisoners; but I forget this sometimes, and there are even moments when my mental vision transports me beyond these walls, and I fancy myself at liberty.”
“But wherefore are you here?”
“Because in 1807 I dreamed of the very plan Napoleon tried to realize in 1811; because, like Machiavelli, I desired to alter the political face of Italy, and instead of allowing it to be split up into a quantity of petty principalities, each held by some weak or tyrannical ruler, I sought to form one large, compact, and powerful empire; and, lastly, because I fancied I had found my Cæsar Borgia in a crowned simpleton, who feigned to enter into my views only to betray me. It was the plan of Alexander VI. and Clement VII., but it will never succeed now, for they attempted it fruitlessly, and Napoleon was unable to complete his work. Italy seems fated to misfortune.” And the old man bowed his head.
Dantès could not understand a man risking his life for such matters. Napoleon certainly he knew something of, inasmuch as he had seen and spoken with him; but of Clement VII. and Alexander VI. he knew nothing.
“Are you not,” he asked, “the priest who here in the Château d’If is generally thought to be—ill?”
“Mad, you mean, don’t you?”
“I did not like to say so,” answered Dantès, smiling.
“Well, then,” resumed Faria with a bitter smile, “let me answer your question in full, by acknowledging that I am the poor mad prisoner of the Château d’If, for many years permitted to amuse the different visitors with what is said to be my insanity; and, in all probability, I should be promoted to the honor of making sport for the children, if such innocent beings could be found in an abode devoted like this to suffering and despair.”

events.title: Faria's Despair and Dantès' Spark of Hope
detailed_summary: After a moment of silent contemplation, Dantès asks Faria if he has completely given up hope of escaping.
Faria responds that he perceives its utter impossibility and now considers it irreverent to attempt what the Almighty evidently does not approve.
Dantès tries to encourage him, suggesting that success should not be expected on the first attempt and questioning why Faria doesn't try a different direction.
Faria explains the immense personal cost of his frustrated effort, detailing the four years spent making tools and two years of arduous digging through rock-hard earth.
He describes the titanic labor of moving huge stones and the difficulty of concealing the excavated debris, which he managed by filling a hollow staircase, now completely choked.

Faria emphasizes that he had meticulously conserved his strength for this single, ultimately dashed, endeavor, and now, with his hopes crushed, nothing will induce him to renew attempts that seem contrary to divine will.
Dantès lowers his head, concealing his elation at having a companion, a feeling that surpasses his sympathy for the abbé's failed escape.
The narrative notes that the idea of escape had never occurred to Dantès before, given the seemingly insurmountable obstacles involved in such an undertaking.
However, witnessing Faria's desperate courage and near success, despite his age and physical weakness, instills new courage and ideas in Dantès.

He reasons that if an older, weaker man could accomplish so much, failing only due to a calculation error, then he, younger and stronger, could surely succeed. Faria's perseverance in creating tools and attempting the escape inspires Dantès to believe it possible for himself.

Dantès contrasts Faria's three years of labor at fifty with his own youth, willing to sacrifice six years, and Faria's scholarly background with his own skills as a hardy sailor and diver, resolving to emulate his companion's bravery.

Dantès remained for a short time mute and motionless; at length he said:
“Then you abandon all hope of escape?”
“I perceive its utter impossibility; and I consider it impious to attempt that which the Almighty evidently does not approve.”
“Nay, be not discouraged. Would it not be expecting too much to hope to succeed at your first attempt? Why not try to find an opening in another direction from that which has so unfortunately failed?”
“Alas, it shows how little notion you can have of all it has cost me to effect a purpose so unexpectedly frustrated, that you talk of beginning over again. In the first place, I was four years making the tools I possess, and have been two years scraping and digging out earth, hard as granite itself; then what toil and fatigue has it not been to remove huge stones I should once have deemed impossible to loosen. Dantès remained for a short time mute and motionless; at length he said:  

“Then it is true—I am free?”  

The words escaped his lips as though he scarcely dared believe them. The walls of his cell, which had been his world for fourteen interminable years, seemed to press in upon him even now, as if reluctant to release their hold. The cold stone beneath his feet, the damp air that had filled his lungs for so long—all of it had become a part of him. And yet, the key had turned in the lock, the door had swung open, and the guard had uttered those impossible words: *You are free.*  

The guard, a burly man with a face hardened by years of indifference, merely shrugged. “That’s what the order says. You’re to be released at once.”  

Dantès took a hesitant step forward, his legs unsteady from years of confinement. The light from the corridor beyond the cell was blinding, and he raised a trembling hand to shield his eyes. How long had it been since he had seen the sun? How long since he had felt its warmth upon his skin?  

“But why?” he whispered, more to himself than to the guard. “Why now?”  

The guard snorted. “Orders come from above. We don’t ask questions.”  

Dantès clenched his fists, his mind racing. Fourteen years of suffering, of despair, of clinging to the hope of justice—and now, without explanation, he was to walk free? It made no sense. Had the truth finally come to light? Had Villefort, Danglars, or Fernand confessed their treachery? Or was this some new cruelty, a trick to raise his hopes only to dash them again?  

He took another step, then another, until he stood at the threshold of his cell. The corridor stretched before him, dimly lit by flickering torches. Somewhere beyond lay the outside world—a world he had once known, a world that had forgotten him.  

“Move along,” the guard grunted, nudging him forward.  

Dantès obeyed, his bare feet whispering against the cold stone. As he walked, the memories of his past life surged within him—his father, his beloved Mercédès, his bright future as a captain. All of it had been stolen from him in a single night. And now, just as suddenly, it was being returned.  

But at what cost?  

He emerged into the prison courtyard, where the sky stretched vast and blue above him. The sun, so long denied to him, bathed his face in golden light. He closed his eyes, breathing deeply of the fresh air, feeling the wind against his skin. For a moment, he was overcome—not with joy, but with a terrible, crushing sorrow.  

*Fourteen years.*  

He had been a boy when he entered this place, full of dreams and love. Now he was a man, hardened by suffering, his heart a desert where only vengeance could take root.  

A voice broke through his thoughts. “Edmond Dantès?”  

He turned to see a stranger—a man in the uniform of a government official, holding a sealed document.  

“Yes,” Dantès replied, his voice rough from disuse.  

“Your release has been signed by the new administration. You are to be given back your belongings and a small sum for your troubles.” The man’s tone was perfunctory, as though he were discussing the weather rather than the ruin of a man’s life.  

Dantès took the document, his hands shaking. “Who ordered this?”  

The official hesitated, then said, “That is not for me to say. But if you wish to know more, I suggest you seek out the Abbé Busoni. He has taken an interest in your case.”  

*The Abbé Busoni.* The name meant nothing to him. Yet another mystery in a life now filled with them.  

Dantès nodded slowly, his mind already turning toward the future. He would find this abbé. He would uncover the truth of his release. And then—  

Then he would settle his accounts.  

With Villefort. With Danglars. With Fernand.  

The world had made him a prisoner. Now it would learn what it meant to make Edmond Dantès its enemy.  

He straightened his shoulders, his eyes burning with a fire that had not been extinguished, only banked.  

“Very well,” he said softly. “I am ready.”  

And with that, Edmond Dantès stepped forward into the light—a free man, but a man forever changed.

Dantès is left confused and silent, recognizing the unspoken moral reasoning that Faria has articulated, distinguishing between ideas of the mind and those of the heart.

After continuing some time in profound meditation, the young man suddenly exclaimed, “I have found what you were in search of!”
Faria started: “Have you, indeed?” cried he, raising his head with quick anxiety; “pray, let me know what it is you have discovered?”
“The corridor through which you have bored your way from the cell you occupy here, extends in the same direction as the outer gallery, does it not?”
“It does.”
“And is not above fifteen feet from it?”
“About that.”
“Well, then, I will tell you what we must do. We must pierce through the corridor by forming a side opening about the middle, as it were the top part of a cross. This time you will lay your plans more accurately; we shall get out into the gallery you have described; kill the sentinel who guards it, and make our escape. All we require to insure success is courage, and that you possess, and strength, which I am not deficient in; as for patience, you have abundantly proved yours—you shall now see me prove mine.”
“One instant, my dear friend,” replied the abbé; “it is clear you do not understand the nature of the courage with which I am endowed, and what use I intend making of my strength. As for patience, I consider that I have abundantly exercised that in beginning every morning the task of the night before, and every night renewing the task of the day. But then, young man (and I pray of you to give me your full attention), then I thought I could not be doing anything displeasing to the Almighty in trying to set an innocent being at liberty—one who had committed no offence, and merited not condemnation.”
“And have your notions changed?” asked Dantès with much surprise; “do you think yourself more guilty in making the attempt since you have encountered me?”
“No; neither do I wish to incur guilt. Hitherto I have fancied myself merely waging war against circumstances, not men. I have thought it no sin to bore through a wall, or destroy a staircase; but I cannot so easily persuade myself to pierce a heart or take away a life.”
A slight movement of surprise escaped Dantès.
“Is it possible,” said he, “that where your liberty is at stake you can allow any such scruple to deter you from obtaining it?”
“Tell me,” replied Faria, “what has hindered you from knocking down your jailer with a piece of wood torn from your bedstead, dressing yourself in his clothes, and endeavoring to escape?”
“Simply the fact that the idea never occurred to me,” answered Dantès.
“Because,” said the old man, “the natural repugnance to the commission of such a crime prevented you from thinking of it; and so it ever is because in simple and allowable things our natural instincts keep us from deviating from the strict line of duty. The tiger, whose nature teaches him to delight in shedding blood, needs but the sense of smell to show him when his prey is within his reach, and by following this instinct he is enabled to measure the leap necessary to permit him to spring on his victim; but man, on the contrary, loathes the idea of blood—it is not alone that the laws of social life inspire him with a shrinking dread of taking life; his natural construction and physiological formation——”
Dantès was confused and silent at this explanation of the thoughts which had unconsciously been working in his mind, or rather soul; for there are two distinct sorts of ideas, those that proceed from the head and those that emanate from the heart.

events.text_segment:
“Since my imprisonment,” said Faria, “I have thought over all the most celebrated cases of escape on record. They have rarely been successful. Those that have been crowned with full success have been long meditated upon, and carefully arranged; such, for instance, as the escape of the Duc de Beaufort from the Château de Vincennes, that of the Abbé Dubuquoi from For l’Evêque; of Latude from the Bastille. Then there are those for which chance sometimes affords opportunity, and those are the best of all. Let us, therefore, wait patiently for some favorable moment, and when it presents itself, profit by it.”
“Ah,” said Dantès, “you might well endure the tedious delay; you were constantly employed in the task you set yourself, and when weary with toil, you had your hopes to refresh and encourage you.”
“I assure you,” replied the old man, “I did not turn to that source for recreation or support.”
“What did you do then?”
“I wrote or studied.”
“Were you then permitted the use of pens, ink, and paper?”
“Oh, no,” answered the abbé; “I had none but what I made for myself.”
“You made paper, pens and ink?”
“Yes.”
Dantès gazed with admiration, but he had some difficulty in believing. Faria saw this.
“When you pay me a visit in my cell, my young friend,” said he, “I will show you an entire work, the fruits of the thoughts and reflections of my whole life; many of them meditated over in the shades of the Colosseum at Rome, at the foot of St. Mark’s column at Venice, and on the borders of the Arno at Florence, little imagining at the time that they would be arranged in order within the walls of the Château d’If. The work I speak of is called A Treatise on the Possibility of a General Monarchy in Italy, and will make one large quarto volume.”
“And on what have you written all this?”
“On two of my shirts. I invented a preparation that makes linen as smooth and as easy to write on as parchment.”
“You are, then, a chemist?”
“Somewhat; I know Lavoisier, and was the intimate friend of Cabanis.”
“But for such a work you must have needed books—had you any?”
“I had nearly five thousand volumes in my library at Rome; but after reading them over many times, I found out that with one hundred and fifty well-chosen books a man possesses, if not a complete summary of all human knowledge, at least all that a man need really know. I devoted three years of my life to reading and studying these one hundred and fifty volumes, till I knew them nearly by heart; so that since I have been in prison, a very slight effort of memory has enabled me to recall their contents as readily as though the pages were open before me. I could recite you the whole of Thucydides, Xenophon, Plutarch, Titus Livius, Tacitus, Strada, Jornandes, Dante, Montaigne, Shakespeare, Spinoza, Machiavelli, and Bossuet. I name only the most important.”
“You are, doubtless, acquainted with a variety of languages, so as to have been able to read all these?”
“Yes, I speak five of the modern tongues—that is to say, German, French, Italian, English, and Spanish; by the aid of ancient Greek I learned modern Greek—I don’t speak it so well as I could wish, but I am still trying to improve myself.”
“Improve yourself!” repeated Dantès; “why, how can you manage to do so?”
“Why, I made a vocabulary of the words I knew; turned, returned, and arranged them, so as to enable me to express my thoughts through their medium. I know nearly one thousand words, which is all that is absolutely necessary, although I believe there are nearly one hundred thousand in the dictionaries. I cannot hope to be very fluent, but I certainly should have no difficulty in explaining my wants and wishes; and that would be quite as much as I should ever require.”
Stronger grew the wonder of Dantès, who almost fancied he had to do with one gifted with supernatural powers; still hoping to find some imperfection which might bring him down to a level with human beings, he added, “Then if you were not furnished with pens, how did you manage to write the work you speak of?”
“I made myself some excellent ones, which would be universally preferred to all others if once known. You are aware what huge whitings are served to us on maigre days. Well, I selected the cartilages of the heads of these fishes, and you can scarcely imagine the delight with which I welcomed the arrival of each Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday, as affording me the means of increasing my stock of pens; for I will freely confess that my historical labors have been my greatest solace and relief. While retracing the past, I forget the present; and traversing at will the path of history I cease to remember that I am myself a prisoner.”
“But the ink,” said Dantès; “of what did you make your ink?”
“There was formerly a fireplace in my dungeon,” replied Faria, “but it was closed up long ere I became an occupant of this prison. Still, it must have been many years in use, for it was thickly covered with a coating of soot; this soot I dissolved in a portion of the wine brought to me every Sunday, and I assure you a better ink cannot be desired. For very important notes, for which closer attention is required, I pricked one of my fingers, and wrote with my own blood.”
“And when,” asked Dantès, “may I see all this?”
“Whenever you please,” replied the abbé.
“Oh, then let it be directly!” exclaimed the young man.
“Follow me, then,” said the abbé, as he re-entered the subterranean passage, in which he soon disappeared, followed by Dantès.

“Since my imprisonment,” said Faria, “I have thought over all the most celebrated cases of escape on record. There have been many, but few have succeeded. The walls of a prison are not merely stone and mortar—they are built of despair, of hopelessness, of the crushing weight of time. Yet, men have always sought freedom, even when the odds seemed insurmountable.”

Edmond Dantès listened intently, his eyes fixed on the old man’s face. Faria’s words carried the weight of years of solitude and reflection. The flickering light of their makeshift lamp cast long shadows on the damp walls of their cell, making the atmosphere feel almost mystical.

“Take, for example, the escape of Latude from the Bastille,” Faria continued. “He spent years crafting ropes from his bedsheets, picking locks with improvised tools, and even disguising himself to slip past guards. His determination was extraordinary, but his success was as much due to luck as to skill. The same can be said of Baron Trenck, who carved his way through stone with a mere nail. These men were driven by an unyielding will, but they also understood the importance of patience.”

Dantès nodded slowly. “Then you believe escape is possible?”

Faria smiled faintly. “Possible, yes. But not without preparation, not without sacrifice. The first lesson is this: to escape a prison, one must first escape despair. The mind must be free before the body can follow.”

He reached beneath his ragged mattress and withdrew a small, carefully folded piece of paper. Unfolding it, he revealed a detailed sketch of the Château d’If, with tunnels, guard rotations, and weak points marked in precise lines. Dantès gasped.

“You’ve mapped the entire prison?”

“Over many years,” Faria admitted. “Every sound, every echo, every crack in the stone has been studied. I have listened to the rhythms of the guards, noted when they are most inattentive, when the tides are high enough to conceal a swimmer. But knowledge alone is not enough. We must also have tools.”

From another hidden crevice, Faria produced a sharpened spoon handle, a length of wire, and a small chisel fashioned from a rusted nail. “These are the beginnings of our arsenal,” he said. “With time, we can make more. But we must work in secret, for discovery would mean death—or worse, separation.”

Dantès felt a surge of hope, but it was tempered by caution. “And if we fail?”

Faria’s expression darkened. “Then we will have tried. But I do not intend to fail. I have waited too long, planned too carefully. And now, with your youth and strength, our chances are greater than ever.”

For weeks, the two men worked in silence, chiseling at the stones behind Faria’s bed. The progress was agonizingly slow, but each tiny fragment of loosened mortar was a victory. They took turns, one keeping watch while the other worked, their ears attuned to the slightest sound of approaching footsteps.

One night, as Dantès labored over the stubborn rock, his hands raw and bleeding, Faria placed a gentle hand on his shoulder. “Rest, my friend. The wall will not yield faster for your suffering. Remember, endurance is our greatest weapon.”

Dantès leaned back, wiping sweat from his brow. “Do you ever wonder what awaits us outside these walls? The world must have changed greatly since you were last free.”

Faria’s eyes grew distant. “I imagine it has. But change is the nature of life. What matters is that we reclaim our place in it. For you, Edmond, there is vengeance to be sought. For me… perhaps only peace.”

The mention of vengeance stirred something deep within Dantès. The faces of those who had betrayed him—Danglars, Fernand, Villefort—flashed in his mind. “They will pay,” he whispered. “Every one of them.”

Faria studied him carefully. “Vengeance is a powerful motivator, but it is a fire that can consume the one who wields it. Be certain it does not blind you to the life you might still live.”

Dantès said nothing, but the hardness in his eyes remained.

Months passed. The tunnel grew longer, their tools sharper, their resolve unshaken. Then, one fateful evening, as Dantès pressed his ear to the wall, he heard something unexpected—the sound of rushing water.

“Faria!” he hissed. “Listen!”

The old man joined him, his face alight with excitement. “A sewer, or perhaps an underground channel. If we can reach it, it may lead us to the sea.”

The discovery renewed their energy. They worked feverishly, their earlier caution giving way to urgency. But just as the final stones began to loosen, disaster struck.

A guard, more alert than usual, noticed the unevenness of the wall during an inspection. With a shout, he called for reinforcements. Faria and Dantès barely had time to conceal their tools before the cell door burst open.

“What is the meaning of this?” the warden demanded, his eyes scanning the room suspiciously.

Faria feigned confusion. “Meaning, sir? We are but two prisoners, praying for mercy.”

The warden was not convinced. He ordered a thorough search, and though their tools remained hidden, the loose stones were discovered. Faria was dragged away for interrogation, leaving Dantès alone in the cell, his heart pounding with fear and fury.

Days passed without word. Then, one morning, the door creaked open, and Faria was thrown back inside, bruised and weakened but alive. Dantès rushed to his side.

“What did they do to you?” he demanded.

Faria coughed weakly. “Nothing… permanent. But they suspect. We must act soon, or we will lose our chance.”

That night, as the prison slept, they made their final preparations. The tunnel was nearly complete; only a few stones stood between them and freedom. With one last, concerted effort, they broke through.

Cold air rushed in, carrying the scent of salt and seaweed. Below them, the dark waters of the Mediterranean churned.

“Now,” Faria whispered, “we leap into the unknown. Are you ready, Edmond?”

Dantès took a deep breath. For the first time in years, he felt truly alive. “Ready.”

And with that, they plunged into the night, leaving the Château d’If behind them. The sea was icy, the current strong, but they swam with the strength of men who had already endured hell. The stars above seemed to guide them, and as the first light of dawn touched the horizon, they knew—they were free.

After having passed with tolerable ease through the subterranean passage, which, however, did not admit of their holding themselves erect, the two friends reached the further end of the corridor, into which the abbé’s cell opened; from that point the passage became much narrower, and barely permitted one to creep through on hands and knees. The floor of the abbé’s cell was paved, and it had been by raising one of the stones in the most obscure corner that Faria had been able to commence the laborious task of which Dantès had witnessed the completion.
As he entered the chamber of his friend, Dantès cast around one eager and searching glance in quest of the expected marvels, but nothing more than common met his view.
“It is well,” said the abbé; “we have some hours before us—it is now just a quarter past twelve o’clock.” Instinctively Dantès turned round to observe by what watch or clock the abbé had been able so accurately to specify the hour.
“Look at this ray of light which enters by my window,” said the abbé, “and then observe the lines traced on the wall. Well, by means of these lines, which are in accordance with the double motion of the earth, and the ellipse it describes round the sun, I am enabled to ascertain the precise hour with more minuteness than if I possessed a watch; for that might be broken or deranged in its movements, while the sun and earth never vary in their appointed paths.”
This last explanation was wholly lost upon Dantès, who had always imagined, from seeing the sun rise from behind the mountains and set in the Mediterranean, that it moved, and not the earth. A double movement of the globe he inhabited, and of which he could feel nothing, appeared to him perfectly impossible. Each word that fell from his companion’s lips seemed fraught with the mysteries of science, as worthy of digging out as the gold and diamonds in the mines of Guzerat and Golconda, which he could just recollect having visited during a voyage made in his earliest youth.
“Come,” said he to the abbé, “I am anxious to see your treasures.”
The abbé smiled, and, proceeding to the disused fireplace, raised, by the help of his chisel, a long stone, which had doubtless been the hearth, beneath which was a cavity of considerable depth, serving as a safe depository of the articles mentioned to Dantès.
